Manpages are in markdown format and will be converted by using ronn, which has an ubuntu package ruby-ronn. They are converted and compressed in the moment of install them.

To complete the pull request, we need info about gzphysics and gzsensors so please, feel free to update the pull request with it or any other fix to man page information.

content.raw: Ok, I've made a fix for the test in ba7bdb2 (branch `manpages_gazebo_fix`). This fix will prevent failure when `gzserver` and `gzclient` are not in the user's `PATH`, or when the `gzserver` and `gzclient` found in the `PATH` have different help strings than the ones under testing.
content.html: Ok, I've made a fix for the test in ba7bdb2 (branch manpages_gazebo_fix). This fix will prevent failure when gzserver and gzclient are not in the user's PATH, or when the gzserver and gzclient found in the PATH have different help strings than the ones under testing.

content.raw:
So I just tried doing that, and `gazebo -h` will run with the expanded `PATH`, but it `escalates to SIGKILL on client` (see [gazebo_main.cc:64](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/dbacc25854a08237960b3532f4367f4b70b0e01a/gazebo/gazebo_main.cc?at=manpages#cl-64))
~~~
# from the build folder
$ PATH=`pwd`/gazebo:`pwd`/gazebo:gui:$PATH gazebo -h
gzserver -- Run the Gazebo server.

`gzserver` [options] <world_file>

Gazebo server runs simulation and handles commandline options, starts a Master, runs World update and sensor generation loops.

Options:
  -q [ --quiet ]                Reduce output to stdout.
  -h [ --help ]                 Produce this help message.
  -u [ --pause ]                Start the server in a paused state.
  -e [ --physics ] arg          Specify a physics engine (ode|bullet).
  -p [ --play ] arg             Play a log file.
  -r [ --record ]               Record state data.
  --record_encoding arg (=zlib) Compression encoding format for log data 
                                (zlib|bz2|txt).
  --record_path arg             Absolute path in which to store state data
  --seed arg                    Start with a given random number seed.
  --iters arg                   Number of iterations to simulate.
  -s [ --server-plugin ] arg    Load a plugin.

[1;Warning [gazebo_main.cc:64] escalating to SIGKILL on client
$
~~~
Running `test/regression/INTEGRATION_manpages` with the similar prepended path will be aborted by the SIGKILL with the following output:
~~~
$ PATH=`pwd`/gazebo:`pwd`/gazebo:gui:$PATH test/regression/INTEGRATION_manpages 
[==========] Running 8 tests from 1 test case.
[----------] Global test environment set-up.
[----------] 8 tests from ManTest
[ RUN      ] ManTest.gzclient
[       OK ] ManTest.gzclient (71 ms)
[ RUN      ] ManTest.gzserver
[       OK ] ManTest.gzserver (63 ms)
[ RUN      ] ManTest.gazebo

$
~~~

# from the build folder

`gzserver` [options] <world_file>

content.raw:
Nice work! I only have one issue now. I've been testing without gazebo installed (cmake .. && make && make test), and it seems that the gazebo manpage test fails. In fact, if gazebo is not installed, I am unable to invoke the built but not installed gazebo (`build/gazebo/gazebo -h` just hangs, while `build/gazebo/gzserver -h` works along with the other commands). Peeking at [gazebo_main.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/dbacc25854a08237960b3532f4367f4b70b0e01a/gazebo/gazebo_main.cc?at=manpages#cl-103), `execvp` is called two times to create processes `gzclient` and `gzserver`. If these commands are not in the `PATH`, then gazebo will hang.

Perhaps the `PATH` environment variable could be prepended with `CMAKE_BINARY_DIR/gazebo:CMAKE_BINARY_DIR/gazebo/gui` for purposes of the gazebo manpage test? I'm going to test this now.
content.html:
Nice work! I only have one issue now. I've been testing without gazebo installed (cmake .. && make && make test), and it seems that the gazebo manpage test fails. In fact, if gazebo is not installed, I am unable to invoke the built but not installed gazebo (build/gazebo/gazebo -h just hangs, while build/gazebo/gzserver -h works along with the other commands). Peeking at gazebo_main.cc, execvp is called two times to create processes gzclient and gzserver. If these commands are not in the PATH, then gazebo will hang.

Perhaps the PATH environment variable could be prepended with CMAKE_BINARY_DIR/gazebo:CMAKE_BINARY_DIR/gazebo/gui for purposes of the gazebo manpage test? I'm going to test this now.

content.raw: Sounds like the safest option to me. It's a pity not to go with the autogeneration, but I'm not able to see a safe way to do it. Manual pages with extra checks using the generator is a far better option than my initial one without any check.
content.html: Sounds like the safest option to me. It's a pity not to go with the autogeneration, but I'm not able to see a safe way to do it. Manual pages with extra checks using the generator is a far better option than my initial one without any check.

content.raw: How about we go back to manual man pages, and we can use the python script for comparing the output of `-h` and the man pages.
content.html: How about we go back to manual man pages, and we can use the python script for comparing the output of -h and the man pages.

content.raw:
You're right, the ronn python script fail if an executable's `-h` option is not available.

I'll make all the suggested changes, and we can re-evaluate whether to go with manual or auto man pages.
content.html:
You're right, the ronn python script fail if an executable's -h option is not available.

I'll make all the suggested changes, and we can re-evaluate whether to go with manual or auto man pages.

content.raw:
Yup, definetly duplicate the entries in command options and man pages is a pain to maintain, specially if they are changing frequently. I'm only consider the option of going with duplication and not making the automation since I believe we are not going to have many updates on them.

Changing stderr to stdout when calling ```-h``` is a good step, IMHO.

More problem should represent the restrictions to writting code which are not controlled (specially by the compiler), in this case:

1. All binaries should implement a ```-h``` command
1. The ```-h``` command should work during the compilation phase.

The auto generation via ```gz_install_executable``` seems a bit obscure to me, but probably it is not a big deal, and indeed, it will force to write ```-h``` commands ... or not, and if someone forgot about writting the ```-h``` the make_ronn probably won't fail. This is one of my fears, end up with bad content in manpages without a failure.

We can try it, if it turns into a pain, we can go back and look for the manual solution.
content.html:
Yup, definetly duplicate the entries in command options and man pages is a pain to maintain, specially if they are changing frequently. I'm only consider the option of going with duplication and not making the automation since I believe we are not going to have many updates on them.

Changing stderr to stdout when calling -h is a good step, IMHO.

More problem should represent the restrictions to writting code which are not controlled (specially by the compiler), in this case:

  1. All binaries should implement a -h command
  2. The -h command should work during the compilation phase.

The auto generation via gz_install_executable seems a bit obscure to me, but probably it is not a big deal, and indeed, it will force to write -h commands ... or not, and if someone forgot about writting the -h the make_ronn probably won't fail. This is one of my fears, end up with bad content in manpages without a failure.

We can try it, if it turns into a pain, we can go back and look for the manual solution.

content.raw:
I can change the help output to direct to stdout. 

`make_ronn` is only run on executables that will be installed. For instance the executable that builds the proto messages is ignored. My view of this is that it will force us to write help output for every installed executable.

If we generate help automatically, then the man pages will never be "out-of-date". As Steve suggested, we should write tests for the help output. There should also be independent tests for each tool, and these will report if a command line tool is functionally incorrect.

I originally did this because man pages separate from `-h` seemed like code duplication, and difficult to maintain.
content.html:
I can change the help output to direct to stdout.

make_ronn is only run on executables that will be installed. For instance the executable that builds the proto messages is ignored. My view of this is that it will force us to write help output for every installed executable.

If we generate help automatically, then the man pages will never be "out-of-date". As Steve suggested, we should write tests for the help output. There should also be independent tests for each tool, and these will report if a command line tool is functionally incorrect.

I originally did this because man pages separate from -h seemed like code duplication, and difficult to maintain.

content.raw: An alternative is to compare the auto-generated man page to a manually curated version as part of a regression test. We could even use the script to update the man page that we keep in revision control, but we would notice changes in diff's and Jenkins test reports.
content.html: An alternative is to compare the auto-generated man page to a manually curated version as part of a regression test. We could even use the script to update the man page that we keep in revision control, but we would notice changes in diff's and Jenkins test reports.

content.raw:
Altough the automation mechanism is really cool, I'm worried that we are introducing a "hack" that could represent limitation to extend funcionality or problems in maintenance in the future. My doubts are:

 * We are somewhat abusing of stderr: if someone call a binary --help, probably would expect result in stdout, not in stderr. There is no error in running that command. Does the code using boost program_options support cerr output? 

 * We are running make_ronn in all generated binaries, expecting them to implement ```-h``` and always generating man pages no matter what output it could produce. 

 * We are running, during compilation, the own results of compilation to generate output and need them to produce the output of ```-h``` without any other code check or code integration (help output need to happen completely independent).

I'm not sure about the goodness of automation this time, but I can live with it if you guys believie that it will produce more happiness than hurt.
content.html:
Altough the automation mechanism is really cool, I'm worried that we are introducing a "hack" that could represent limitation to extend funcionality or problems in maintenance in the future. My doubts are:

  • We are somewhat abusing of stderr: if someone call a binary --help, probably would expect result in stdout, not in stderr. There is no error in running that command. Does the code using boost program_options support cerr output?

  • We are running make_ronn in all generated binaries, expecting them to implement -h and always generating man pages no matter what output it could produce.

  • We are running, during compilation, the own results of compilation to generate output and need them to produce the output of -h without any other code check or code integration (help output need to happen completely independent).

I'm not sure about the goodness of automation this time, but I can live with it if you guys believie that it will produce more happiness than hurt.

content.raw:
The gzfactory man page has different formatting in the options section:
~~~
OPTIONS
       ·   -h, --help produce this help message

       ·   -f, --sdf arg : SDF model file.

       ·   -w, --world-name arg : Name of Gazebo world.

       ·   -m, --model-name arg : Model name.

       ·   -x, --pose-x arg set model x position.

       ·   -y, --pose-y arg set model y position.

       ·   -z, --pose-z arg set model z positione.

       ·   -R, --pose-R arg set model roll orientation in radians.

       ·   -P, --pose-P arg set model pitch orientation in radians.

       ·   -Y, --pose-Y arg set model yaw orientation in radians.

~~~
The gzlog man page looks better I think:
~~~
OPTIONS
       -h, --help
              Output this help message.

       -r, --raw
              Output the data from echo and step without XML formatting.

       -s, --stamp arg
              Add a timestamp to each line of output. Valid values are (sim,real,wall)

       -z, --hz arg
              Filter  output  to the specified Hz rate.Only valid for echo and step com‐
              mands.

       -f, --file arg
              Path to a log file.

       --filter arg
              Filter output. Valid only for the echo and step commands

~~~
content.html:
The gzfactory man page has different formatting in the options section:

OPTIONS
       ·   -h, --help produce this help message

       ·   -f, --sdf arg : SDF model file.

       ·   -w, --world-name arg : Name of Gazebo world.

       ·   -m, --model-name arg : Model name.

       ·   -x, --pose-x arg set model x position.

       ·   -y, --pose-y arg set model y position.

       ·   -z, --pose-z arg set model z positione.

       ·   -R, --pose-R arg set model roll orientation in radians.

       ·   -P, --pose-P arg set model pitch orientation in radians.

       ·   -Y, --pose-Y arg set model yaw orientation in radians.

The gzlog man page looks better I think:

OPTIONS
       -h, --help
              Output this help message.

       -r, --raw
              Output the data from echo and step without XML formatting.

       -s, --stamp arg
              Add a timestamp to each line of output. Valid values are (sim,real,wall)

       -z, --hz arg
              Filter  output  to the specified Hz rate.Only valid for echo and step com‐
              mands.

       -f, --file arg
              Path to a log file.

       --filter arg
              Filter output. Valid only for the echo and step commands

content.raw: These lines are being executed during configure (ie. `cmake ..`) before the binaries have been built. So it will fail if gazebo has never been installed, and it will use the wrong binaries if a different version is already installed. The man page should be generated after the build.
content.html: These lines are being executed during configure (ie. cmake ..) before the binaries have been built. So it will fail if gazebo has never been installed, and it will use the wrong binaries if a different version is already installed. The man page should be generated after the build.

content.raw:
I'm taking a crack at this.

Okay version 1 is in 4c24bc0 and is a major hack-fest (inspired by [some of Morgan's code](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sandia-hand/src/215d9c5f840dad907d453e1af0442ca13b5af97e/ros/sandia_hand_description/robots/gazebo_manifest_generator.sh)):
~~~
hg pull -b manpages_scpeters
sh gazebo/gazebo_ronn_generator.bash
~~~
content.html:
I'm taking a crack at this.

Okay version 1 is in 4c24bc0 and is a major hack-fest (inspired by some of Morgan's code):

hg pull -b manpages_scpeters
sh gazebo/gazebo_ronn_generator.bash

content.raw: Agreed that these should be outside the scope of this pull request. For the test, I was thinking of a hack that parses `gzserver --help` and compares it to the markdown source in some way.

content.raw:
Both are good ideas:

1. I can not find a way to share content between the ronn which does not imply a local hack. I would like to avoid it and I would say that the number of expected modifications on the man page are not enough to use a local hack.

2. Interesting. I was not able to find any software which automatically from the man page, does the trick. We will need a parser on roff and format and find a reliable way of checking the result. I would say better to think about it outside of the scope of this pull request.
content.html:
Both are good ideas:

  1. I can not find a way to share content between the ronn which does not imply a local hack. I would like to avoid it and I would say that the number of expected modifications on the man page are not enough to use a local hack.

content.raw:
`gazebo` and `gzserver` have the same command-line arguments. Perhaps we can generate this part of the man page from the same source?

Also, maybe we should have a test to make sure that our command-line parameters are all in the man pages.
content.html:
gazebo and gzserver have the same command-line arguments. Perhaps we can generate this part of the man page from the same source?

Also, maybe we should have a test to make sure that our command-line parameters are all in the man pages.
